natural problem: Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$.
natural solution: We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.

Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\

&\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.

For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int" and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "a 3 = 123"
and h1 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. a n = concat (map show [1..n])"
and h3 : "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.
 Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\
 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int" and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "a 3 = 123"
and h1 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. a n = concat (map show [1..n])"
and h3 : "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider a function $a(n)$ that concatenates the sequence of integers from 1 to $n$ into a single number. For example, $a(3)=123$ and $a(11)=1234567891011$. Find the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by 45. The final answer is $9$.

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 3 = 123"
and h1 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. a n = (concatenate numbers from 1 to n)"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"

a_1.informal problem: A function $a$ is defined such that $a(n)$ concatenates the numbers from $1$ to $n$. For example, $a(3) = 123$ and $a(11) = 1234567891011$. What is the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by $45$? The final answer is $9$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "a 2 = 12"
and h2 : "a 3 = 123"
and h3 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h4 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 4. a n = a (n-1) * 10^length(n-1) + n"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9

 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.

In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "a 2 = 12"
and h2 : "a 3 = 123"
and h3 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h4 : "\<forall> n \<ge> 4. a n = a (n-1) * 10^length(n-1) + n"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Define an integer function $a(n)$ such that $a(1) = 1$, $a(2) = 12$, $a(3) = 123$, $a(11) = 1234567891011$ and for $n \geq 4, a(n) = a(n-1) * 10^{\text{length of digits in } (n-1)} + n$. What is the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by $45$? The final answer is $9$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. a n = concat [1 .. n]"
and h1 : "\<exists>k. a 44 = 45 * k + r"
shows  "r = 9"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.
 Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\
 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. a n = concat [1 .. n]"
and h1 : "\<exists>k. a 44 = 45 * k + r"
shows  "r = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Suppose we have a sequence defined by $a(n) = 1 + 2 + \ldots + n$ for all natural numbers $n$. Find the remainder, $r$, when $a(44)$ is divided by $45$. The final answer is $9$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "a 3 = 123"
and h1 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> a n = n * (10 powr (n - 1)) + a (n - 1)"
shows  "(a 44) mod 45 = 9"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.

 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "a 3 = 123"
and h1 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 3 \<longrightarrow> a n = n * (10 powr (n - 1)) + a (n - 1)"
shows  "(a 44) mod 45 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A sequence $a$ is defined by $a(3) = 123$, $a(11) = 1234567891011$, and for all natural numbers $n \geq 3$, $a(n) = n \times 10^{n - 1} + a(n - 1)$. What is the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by $45$? The final answer is $9$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and n :: int
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "a 2 = 12"
and h2 : "a 3 = 123"
and h3 : "\<forall>n > 3. a n = concat (a (n-1)) n"
and h4 : "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.

In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int" and n :: int
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "a 2 = 12"
and h2 : "a 3 = 123"
and h3 : "\<forall>n > 3. a n = concat (a (n-1)) n"
and h4 : "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A sequence of integers $a$ is defined such that $a(1) = 1$, $a(2) = 12$, $a(3) = 123$, and for all integers $n > 3$, $a(n)$ is the concatenation of $a(n-1)$ and $n$. Given that the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by $45$ is $9$, show that the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by $45$ is still $9$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "a 3 = 123"
and h2 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 12 \<longrightarrow> a n = a (n-1) * 10^(nat (length (show n))) + n"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.
 Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\
 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "a 3 = 123"
and h2 : "a 11 = 1234567891011"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 12 \<longrightarrow> a n = a (n-1) * 10^(nat (length (show n))) + n"
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a function $a$ where $a(1)=1$, $a(3)=123$, $a(11)=1234567891011$, and for all integers $n \geq 12$, $a(n) = a(n-1) * 10^{(the number of digits in n)} + n$. What is the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by 45? The final answer is 9.

a_7.formal problem:
fun a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
where
  "a n = (if n = 1 then 1 else a (n - 1) * 10 ^ (length (show n)) + n)"

theorem
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
using a.simps by simp

end
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.
 Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\
 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)



fun a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
where
  "a n = (if n = 1 then 1 else a (n - 1) * 10 ^ (length (show n)) + n)"

theorem
shows  "a 44 mod 45 = 9"
using a.simps by simp

end
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Define a sequence $a(n)$ for integer $n$ as follows: $a(1) = 1$ and for $n > 1$, $a(n) = a(n - 1) * 10^{(number of digits in n)} + n$. Find the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by 45. The final answer is 9.

a_8.formal problem:
function a_n :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int" where
"a_n 0 = 0" |
"a_n n = a_n (n - 1) * (10 ^ (length (digits n))) + n"

theorem
shows  "a_n 44 mod 45 = 9"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.
 Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\
 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

function a_n :: "nat \<Rightarrow> int" where
"a_n 0 = 0" |
"a_n n = a_n (n - 1) * (10 ^ (length (digits n))) + n"

theorem
shows  "a_n 44 mod 45 = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A function a_n is defined as follows: a_n(0) is 0 and for any natural number n, a_n(n) equals to a_n(n - 1) multiplied by (10 to the power of the number of digits in n) plus n. Find the remainder when a_n(44) is divided by 45. The final answer is 9.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> a n = concat (a (n-1)) n"
and h2 : "a 44 mod 45 = r"
shows  "r = 9"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $a_n$ be the integer obtained by writing all the integers from $1$ to $n$ from left to right. For example, $a_3 = 123$ and $a_{11} = 1234567891011$. Compute the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by $45$. The final Answer is 9
 ### Proof
 We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem as follows: We will compute the remainders when $a_{44}$ is divided by $5$ and $9$. The remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 will be the residue (mod 45) which leaves the same remainders when divided by 5 and 9 as $a_{44}$ does.
 Since $a_{44}$ ends in $4$, it gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. For the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 9, note that  \begin{align} a_{44}&=44+43\cdot 10^2 + 42 \cdot 10^4+41\cdot 10^6+\cdots+10\cdot10^{68}\\
 &\qquad+9\cdot 10^{70}+8\cdot 10^{71}+\cdots + 1\cdot 10^{78} \\ &\equiv 44+43+42+\cdots+1\pmod{9}, \end{align}since $10^n\equiv 1^n\equiv 1\pmod{9}$ for all nonnegative integers $n$. In words, this calculation shows that we can sum groups of digits in any way we choose to check for divisibility by 9.
 For example, 1233 is divisible by 9 since $12+33=45$ is divisible by 9. This is a generalization of the rule that a number is divisible by 9 if and only if the sum of its digits is divisible by 9. Getting back to the problem at hand, we sum $44+43+\cdots+1$ using the formula $1+2+\cdots+n=n(n+1)/2$ to find that $a_{44}$ is divisible by 9.
 We are looking for a multiple of $9$ that gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $5$. Nine satisfies this condition, so the remainder when $a_{44}$ is divided by 45 is $\boxed{9}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> a n = concat (a (n-1)) n"
and h2 : "a 44 mod 45 = r"
shows  "r = 9"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A function $a$ is defined such that $a(1) = 1$ and for all integers $n > 1$, $a(n)$ is the concatenation of $a(n-1)$ and $n$. What is the remainder when $a(44)$ is divided by 45? The final answer is 9.
